awd_titl_txt: Scalable Nanomanufacturing of Large-area Two-dimensional Tellurene for High-performance Wearable Piezoelectric Devices
awd_abstract_narration:
Piezoelectric nanomaterials convert mechanical signals into electrical power and promise to revolutionize emerging self-powered technologies. Current methods for making piezoelectric nanomaterials are restricted by growth substrates, reaction pressure and temperature, which limits their economic manufacture. This award supports fundamental research to provide needed knowledge for the development of a low-temperature, substrate-free, scalable nanomanufacturing process. The novel process involves solution-based nanomanufacturing of a new piezoelectric nanomaterial, two-dimensional tellurene, with high productivity and high quality. Piezoelectric nanomaterials exhibit superior mechanical and piezoelectric properties to their bulk counterparts and are increasingly preferred for applications in energy, healthcare, sensors, and biomedical and wearable devices. Therefore, results from this research benefits the U.S. economy and society. This research involves several disciplines including manufacturing, materials science, electrical engineering, device physics, and data science. The multi-disciplinary approach helps broaden participation of women and underrepresented groups in research and positively impacts engineering education.

Hydrothermal solution process can overcome several limitations existing in nanomaterial manufacturing. These range from energy budget, scalability, environmental control, and working temperature. However, some scientific barriers are yet to be overcome to realize the full potential of the hydrothermal solution process for manufacturing of 2D nanomaterials. This research is will fill the knowledge gap on the mechanisms for the 2D tellurene formation during hydrothermal synthesis. The objectives are (1) to explore the unique advantage and capability of low-cost, scalable solution-based manufacturing for growth of tellurene nanomaterials with control over their production yield, morphology and dimensions, and (2) to uncover the process-structure-property-functionality relationships in designing, manufacturing, and integrating the tellurene-based wearable piezoelectric nanodevices. The research team will pursue a physics-based theoretical model to predict the structural and piezoelectric properties of tellurene manufactured by the hydrothermal process and conduct experiments to verify the model. The research team will test the hypothesis that surfactant type and concentration are the determining factors for controlling the thickness and hence the piezoelectric behavior of tellurene, and in so doing, will establish the relationships between process parameters and material functionality (e.g., piezoelectricity) in hydrothermal nanomanufacturing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
To create competitive nanomanufacturing of emerging atomically thin crystals, hydrothermal synthesis was investigated. This study aims to comprehend the fundamental mechanism and effect of solution process variables on the production yield and dimension control of tellurene, as well as to establish the process-structure-property-function relationship at the process and assembly levels of tellurene-based piezoelectric nanodevices. The outcomes are summarized in the following: 

(1)   A systematic, data-driven methodology for understanding and learning the effects of hydrothermal process variables on the production yield, dimensions, and application-specific properties of tellurene was established. The essential relationship between three crucial synthetic parameters—reaction time, precursor concentration, and pH value—was unraveled. For the first time, an integrated physics-based and data-driven nanomanufacturing platform was investigated and established using interpretable machine learning (IML) to identify and elucidate the process-structure-property relationships in the scalable production of 2D piezoelectric tellurene with controlled dimensions for the targeted device functionalities. The team gains a much deeper understanding of the thermodynamic and kinetic mechanisms governing the synthesis of tellurene with the desired quality and characteristics.

(2)   The fundamental piezoelectric-relevant parameters (e.g., Young's modulus, piezoelectric coefficient, carrier concentration, etc.) in elemental tellurene were systematically characterized for the first time using the high-quality tellurene crystals produced. In addition, the effects of tellurene thickness (and hence the manufacturing conditions) on these piezoelectric-relevant properties were investigated and identified.

(3)   Two protocols were explored and established to introduce strain engineering with a broad tunability in solution-synthesized tellurene crystals. The first protocol used stretchable polymeric substrates to induce buckling in transferred tellurene. In the second protocol, nanoimprinting was applied to introduce large-scale, parallel forming in Te nanostructures and make related materials into wrinkled structures with controlled periodicities, amplitudes, and orientations at a large scale with nanoscale resolutions. With such capability, the strain-engineered material properties of tellurene were further explored, including its fundamental electrical, mechanical, optical, and phase transition properties during straining. Systematic computational efforts have also been devoted to elucidating the structure-property correlations for the piezoelectric behavior in tellurene and exploring the intriguing inversion symmetry-breaking mechanisms.

(4)   The integration of solution-manufactured tellurene crystals into wearable piezoelectric devices was demonstrated for human-integrated sensing applications. In the first scheme, Langmuir-Blodgett (LB) method was used to assemble solution-synthesized tellurene into stretchable piezoelectric devices. The second scheme adopted a hybrid printing method that integrates highly complementary aerosol jet printing and extrusion printing in a single printing platform to achieve all-printed Te-based piezoelectric wearable devices. With such developed capability, the feasibility of Te-based wearable devices for human-integrated sensing applications, e.g., gesture detection and pulse measurement, was explored and characterized. 

 


Last Modified: 07/30/2022
Modified by: Wenzhuo Wu
